description: [Status: stable] [Name: logging-too-many-args] [Message: Too many arguments for logging format string] What it does Checks for too many positional arguments for a logging format string. Why is this bad? A TypeError will be raised if the statement is run. Example import logging try: function() except Exception as e: logging.error("Error occurred: %s", type(e), e) raise Use instead: import logging try: function() except Exception as e: logging.error("%s error occurred: %s", type(e), e) raise

lint.logger-objects.option_description:
A list of objects that should be treated equivalently to a
logging.Logger object.

This is useful for ensuring proper diagnostics (e.g., to identify
logging deprecations and other best-practices) for projects that
re-export a logging.Logger object from a common module.

For example, if you have a module logging_setup.py with the following
contents:
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

Adding "logging_setup.logger" to logger-objects will ensure that
logging_setup.logger is treated as a logging.Logger object when
imported from other modules (e.g., from logging_setup import logger).



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff.lint]
logger-objects = ["logging_setup.logger"]



[lint]
logger-objects = ["logging_setup.logger"]
